We sacrifice the safety of others by creating chaos instead of pursuing a path to protect the rights of all Americans, regardless of color.
But violence, looting, and arson are not the answer. Not even close.
There are important issues in this country that need to be confronted, communicated, and worked through in the spirit of community.
Our heart goes out to Michael Brown's family for their tragic loss.
My wife and I have raised three sons, and we know the challenges a young, black man faces growing up.
This fight for justice, in #Ferguson and all over, demands far more firmness of purpose than a fight in the street.
This, however, is not the work of a moment but of a movement, and it will take a coalition, not a confrontation.
If they do not hear our cries in the street, let them hear us in the voting booth.
We wholeheartedly agree. Let us memorialize, but let us also mobilize. Let us change #Ferguson so that the entire nation would take note.
We have heard, with sympathetic ears, the frustrations and fears of young people. They have told us something must be done.
They will raise their voices. They will chant. They will preach. They will cry.
Tonight, many in #Ferguson will no doubt express their pain and angst publicly. They will raise their hands saying, hands up, don‚Äôt shoot.
We have not merely witnessed the effects of a warped sense of law & order, enforced with unbridled & unpredictable power. We wear the scars.
African-Americans have long believed that police resort to force incautiously when dealing with their young men.
We hear you. And we hurt with you. All decent Americans, black, white, brown, should also feel the pain of this family, this  community.
Remember, young people of #Ferguson, your pain is not wrong. Your feelings are valid. We understand you‚Äôre hurt.
